case_vignette: A 28-year-old G2P1 female is concerned that she may give birth to another child with Down syndrome. She states that she may not be able to take care of another child with this disorder.
question: Which  tests can confirm the diagnosis of Down syndrome in utero?

Great! There are several types of prenatal tests available that can help identify potential genetic abnormalities in your baby. Here are some of the most common tests:

1. First Trimester Screening (FTS): This test is typically done between 10-13 weeks of pregnancy and provides an estimate of the risk of Down syndrome and other genetic disorders. It combines ultrasound measurements of the fetus with a blood test to assess the risk.
2. Second Trimester Screening (STS): This test is typically done between 15-20 weeks of pregnancy and provides a more detailed assessment of the risk of Down syndrome and other genetic disorders. It includes an ultrasound examination of the fetus and a blood test to measure the levels of certain proteins in the mother's blood.
